concept.title: Introduction to DITA

section.p: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture (DITA) is an XML-based architecture for authoring, producing, and delivering topic-oriented, information-typed content that can be reused and single-sourced in a variety of ways. While DITA historically has been driven by the requirements of large-scale technical documentation authoring, management, and delivery, it is a standard that is applicable to any kind of publication or information that might be presented to readers, including interactive training and educational materials, standards, reports, business documents, trade books, travel and nature guides, and more.

DITA is designed for creating new document types and describing new information domains based on existing types and domains. The process for creating new types and domains is called specialization. Specialization enables the creation of specific, targeted XML grammars that can still use tools and design rules that were developed for more general types and domains; this is similar to how classes in an object-oriented system can inherit the methods of ancestor classes.

Because DITA topics are conforming XML documents, they can be readily viewed, edited, and validated using standard XML tools, although realizing the full potential of DITA requires using DITA-aware tools.

reference.title: Organisation of DITA elements

example.p: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
DITA elements can be broadly categorized as follows:

In fact, this is how the DITA Language Reference groups DITA elements. This categorization of the various elements is partly to aid understanding, and partly to make it technically easier for the schema files (DTD and XSD) to be managed.
Elements used within topics can also be differently categorized as block or phrase elements.

reference.title: Topic Elements

example.p: The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.

The topic elements are the main structural elements of topics. Some topic elements are generic (that's inherited from the topic proto information type), while others are specific to the concept, task or reference information types.

reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)
reference.title: Map Elements

example.p: The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The map elements are a small set of elements, some of which have been specialised into other elements for use in bookmaps.

reference.title: Body Elements

example.p: The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
Body elements are the most common content authoring block elements, and include:

reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic abbrev-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (topic equation-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic mathml-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic svg-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)
reference.title: Prolog Elements

example.p: A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The DITAprolog elements contain the main metadata for a topic or collection.
The types of information recorded in the prolog include:

ul.li: permissions for use/management of the content
extensive metadata about the content of the document

concept.title: Domain Elements

conbody.p: The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.
Remembering that DITA started life within IBM as a tool for creating software and hardware documentation, it shouldn't be a surprise to discover that DITA's base elements reflect that background.
Elements that relate to a particular field (such as software) are called domain elements. The domain elements within DITA are grouped into:

dlentry.dd: generic word-processor like elements used to highlight text
terms and structures related to programming environments
terms and structures related to the operation of a software program
elements that relate to table structures
terms and structures related to a software user interface
elements that don't fit anywhere else!

conbody.p: If you are writing a programmer's reference, you will mainly use elements in theprogramming domain.
If you are writing a mobile phone user guide, you should avoid using programming domain elements, and mainly use user interface domain elements.

The typographical domain elements are designed to be used only when no semantically- appropriate elements are available and a formatting effect is required. These elements should therefore only be used as a last resort.

reference.title: Programming domain elements

section.p: The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
Note: Use <dl> to describe each of the following element and provide an example.

row.entry: one of a set of options
group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagram)
choice of a group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
group of composite syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
fragment of syntax (used only for syntax diagrams
cross-reference to a fragment of syntax
block of small pieces of syntax
syntax keyword (used only for syntax diagrams)
variable that a user must supply (used only for syntax diagrams)
operator character (such as +, -, and =) within syntax
delimiter character (such as /, |, and ;) within syntax
separator character for repeated syntax elements

section.p: The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.

row.entry: variable (to be provided by user) name
file name or path, or URI

reference.title: Utilities domain elements

section.p: The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.
Note: Use <dl> to describe each of the following element and provide an example.

row.entry: hotspot area within an image map
co-ordinates of a hotspot area within an image map
shape of a hotspot area within an image map
